newsitem.title: GERMANY: TENNIS-BECKER BEATS PAIN TO JOIN SAMPRAS IN THIRD ROUND.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-BECKER BEATS PAIN TO JOIN SAMPRAS IN THIRD ROUND.

text.p: Australian Open champion Boris Becker won a serving shoot-out with Briton Greg Rusedski in his opening match of the Stuttgart Open on Wednesday but acknowledged afterwards he was still playing in pain.
Becker, trying to get back to his best after suffering a serious wrist injury at this year's Wimbledon, delighted his home crowd with a 6-4 6-4 second round victory.

The three-times Wimbledon champion joined the tournament's other big draws Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi in the third round. But the German said afterwards: "The more I play, the more it hurts. But it comes with the package.
"The injury has gone but because I had a cast for so long some of the muscles disappeared. I can only get them back by playing tournaments."
World number one Sampras had few problems in disposing Armenian Sargis Sargsian 6-3 6-4 while Agassi beat Spaniard Alberto Berasategui 6-1 7-6.
Becker needs good results at the $2.2 million event to ensure a place at next month's season-ending world championship in Hanover. The German won the title last year.
But he said his main goal at the moment was simply getting fit enough to play.

"Sometimes going to the doctor has been more exhausting than playing tournaments," he said. "But my priority at the moment has been on getting fit. It would be nice to make it to Hanover but I have only been thinking about my body recently."
When Becker is playing in front of his fanatical German supporters, it is hard not to feel sympathy for his opponent.

Although he missed several key chances to get a grip on the match, the Canadian-born Rusedski played some crisp volleys and passing shots, but only a handful of people put their hands together to applaude them.
By contrast they roared every movement from Becker.

Becker took an early initiative with a service break in the third game when Rusedski netted a forehand. Although the German was not serving at his best, he clinched the first set after 39 minutes when the Briton hit a wide service return.
In the ninth game of the second set the German hit a superb forehand passing shot to break again and lead 5-4. In the next game he fired an ace to wrap-up the match in 68 minutes.
Earlier, defending champion and third seed Thomas Muster limped out of the tournament with a recurring hip injury.
Australia's Mark Woodforde was leading 3-0 in the deciding third set when the Austrian hobbled off the court.
"I have had this for a few years and it is not getting better," said Muster. "If I knew what to do with it I would be a doctor, not a tennis player."
Former world number one Stefan Edberg, playing his last year on the tour, also went out in the second round losing 7-6 6-3 to Croatia's fifth seed Goran Ivanisevic.
